issue.title: "Possible precedence problem between ! and numeric eq (==)" failure in automake
issue.body:
<!--
Note: you can also replace the whole content with a file generated by the perlbug utility;
perlbug reports by email are no longer supported.
Be sure to enclose your perl configuration in a fenced code block to preserve formatting:
https://help.github.com/en/github/writing-on-github/creating-and-highlighting-code-blocks
-->

<!--
If your bug is about a Perl core module rather than a core language
feature, please enter its name after.
-->
Module:

**Description**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
When using Perl 5.41.7 or Perl 5.41.8, we are seeing this error message appear when running automake (written in perl).
Perl 5.41.3 did not have this problem.
```
Possible precedence problem between ! and numeric eq (==) at /data/zopen/usr/local/zopen/automake/automake-1.17.20241029_040611.zos/bin/automake line 6875.
```
Is this expected? It's preventing us from building autotools based projects.

Here's the reduced snippet of what automake is doing:
```
# test.pl
use strict;
use warnings;

sub transform_token {
    my ($token, $transform_ref, $key) = @_;
    return exists $transform_ref->{$key} ? $transform_ref->{$key} : '';
}

sub transform {
    my ($token, $transform) = @_;

    if ($token =~ /^%([\w\-]+)%$/) {
        return transform_token($token, $transform, $1);
    }
    elsif ($token =~ /^%\?([\w\-]+)%$/) {
        return transform_token($token, $transform, $1) ? 'TRUE' : 'FALSE';
    }
    elsif ($token =~ /^ \? (!?) ([\w\-]+) \? $/x) {
        my $neg = ($1 eq '!') ? 1 : 0;
        my $val = transform_token($token, $transform, $2);
        return (!!$val == $neg) ? '##%' : '';
    }
    else {
        die "Unknown request format: $token";
    }
}

# Simple test cases
my %transform_data = (
    'KEY1' => 'VALUE1',
    'KEY2' => '',
    'KEY3' => '1',
);

print transform('?KEY3?', \%transform_data) eq '##%' ? "PASS\n" : "FAIL\n";
```

**Steps to Reproduce**
<!-- A one-liner or script to reproduce the issue. -->
```
perl test.pl
```

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->
No "Possible precedence problem between ! and numeric eq (==)" message

**Perl configuration**
<!-- Please paste `perl -V` output just below. -->

issue.title: fix precedence issue in runtests.pl

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
The condition `!$cmdtype eq "perl"` (introduced in a4765b0551) is always false. It checks whether a logical negation (giving true/false) is equal to the string `"perl"`. This is impossible, so the logging never worked.

The intent was probably to negate the result of the string comparison:`!($cmdtype eq "perl")` or simply `$cmdtype ne "perl"`.

Fixes #16128.

body:
The affected line does
~~~
if(!$cmdtype eq "perl")
~~~
This is wrong, and perl is rightly giving a warning here. The code is equivalent to
~~~
if (not($cmdtype) eq "perl")
~~~
when what was undoubtedly meant was
~~~
if ($cmdtype ne "perl")
~~~

Also note that the script has set ¬´use warnings FATAL => 'all';¬ª. That promotes these warnings to exceptions. I'm not sure that's a good idea for a script like this where you can't control the version of perl other people will run it on: it means that any existent version of curl can break with a future perl when it adds a warning like this. It's probably more appropriate to use non-fatal warnings here.

issue.title: scripts: make Perl warnings errors in tests and CI

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Follow-up to 2ec54556d4e3f3ab551b5298adab0c703d85a463 #17877

---

- [x] move off fixes to a separate PR ‚Üí #18047

Unexpected/unhandled warnings can cause (and have caused)
tests to silently not execute or not run as intented. To catch these
early, it'd be useful to make warnings fatal.

But, this has the potential downside of making scripts fail when
run on a newer (older?/different?) Perl version throwing warnings
not seen in CI, or on local development machine. This happend
once in the past and decided to do the reverse of this PR (for
`runtests.pl`, which was the only script promoting warnings to errors):

9712db21d1786f208bedd8796773d38d9f7128fa #16128
https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/16128#issuecomment-2626236565

How to make Perl warnings fatal in CI only?
